channel.title: Brandon Boswell
channel.description: Recent content from Brandon Boswell's Digital Garden

item.title: No niche is too small with the internet
item.description: The easiest way to find your people is to post about that niche online. Most people will never find it or will see it and move on, but the people you want to chat with will find you and connect. It also helps if you reach out to others who are posting and sharing their interest in your desired topics. This is the single best way I’ve found to build a Scenius.
item.content:encoded: The easiest way to find your people is to post about that niche online. Most people will never find it or will see it and move on, but the people you want to chat with will find you and connect. It also helps if you reach out to others who are posting and sharing their interest in your desired topics. This is the single best way I’ve found to build a Scenius.

item.title: Scenius
item.description: Term coined by Brian Eno. “Scenius is like genius, only embedded in a scene rather than in genes.”
item.content:encoded:
Term coined by Brian Eno.

“Scenius is like genius, only embedded in a scene rather than in genes.”

item.title: Membership
item.description: I really like the idea of an app or a service calling their paid offering a membership. Perhaps it’s not quite a community, but it’s creating a similar feeling that you’re part of something. It’s less transactional in nature. There are likely some cooling things you can do with Badging. That could be nice. I’ve heard of this in the past, but I feel like the Arc team truly understands this. I feel like Muse understands this as well. Things that I build in the future, should probably do the same thing. It’s kind of like Patreon on steroids where there’s some software component, there’s some support component, and some community engagement component.
item.content:encoded:
I really like the idea of an app or a service calling their paid offering a membership. Perhaps it’s not quite a community, but it’s creating a similar feeling that you’re part of something. It’s less transactional in nature. There are likely some cooling things you can do with Badging. That could be nice. I’ve heard of this in the past, but I feel like the Arc team truly understands this. I feel like Muse understands this as well.

Things that I build in the future, should probably do the same thing. It’s kind of like Patreon on steroids where there’s some software component, there’s some support component, and some community engagement component. Perhaps that would need to change over time if the community grows larger, but I think it’s a great place to start.

item.title: Good writers are navigating their readers through an unfamiliar world
item.description: Honestly, Design is very similar. We are navigating a user through an unfamiliar world and are giving them tools and directions in order to navigate it.
item.content:encoded: Honestly, Design is very similar. We are navigating a user through an unfamiliar world and are giving them tools and directions in order to navigate it.

item.title: Spatial Computing
item.description: When I think of spatial computing, I think about a form of augmented reality where windows occupy physical space, and they stay put like a physical object. Apple Vision Pro
item.content:encoded:
When I think of spatial computing, I think about a form of augmented reality where windows occupy physical space, and they stay put like a physical object.

Apple Vision Pro

item.title: Apple Vision Pro
item.description: There are some really interesting mods and adjustments that can be done to improve the Apple Vision Pro. The first of which is removing the light seal. It significantly improves the FOV and opens up your peripheral vision. The only issue is it puts a lot of weight on the bridge of your nose. But if you do like in the following link and use rubber bands to attach it to a hat, the weight balance is much more even and significantly more comfortable. https://twitter.com/haltor/status/1753875008953205132
item.content:encoded: There are some really interesting mods and adjustments that can be done to improve the Apple Vision Pro. The first of which is removing the light seal. It significantly improves the FOV and opens up your peripheral vision. The only issue is it puts a lot of weight on the bridge of your nose. But if you do like in the following link and use rubber bands to attach it to a hat, the weight balance is much more even and significantly more comfortable. https://twitter.com/haltor/status/1753875008953205132
